1.title: Episode 1
1.content: You want to buy clothes from a Facebook shop offering lower-than-usual prices. The shop has no reviews but a lot of followers. The deal is made, and they sent you their bank account number. What will you do?

choices.text: Transfer money because the shop has many followers, seems trustworthy.
Suspicious? Better check the account name on scam databases.
Don’t want to risk it, better ask for more seller credentials...

correct1.title: Great job
correct1.content: You did the right thing. As a buyer, you have the right to verify before transferring. Well done — keep it up!

wrong1.title: Oh no...
wrong1.content: You encountered a giant dragon in a cave.

2.title: Episode 2
2.content: You use the same password for multiple websites for convenience. One site got hacked. What will you do?

choices.text: Ignore it because the other sites probably won't be affected.
Change all passwords immediately and enable 2FA if possible.
Keep using the same password because it's easy to remember.

correct2.title: Well done!
correct2.content: Changing passwords and enabling 2FA is the safest way when accounts are at risk. You care about your data security — excellent!

wrong2.title: Oh no...
wrong2.content: Using repeated passwords or not changing them might lead to other accounts getting hacked. Be careful with your information!

3.title: Episode 3
3.content: You receive an email that looks like it's from your bank saying your account is locked and asking you to click a link. What will you do?

choices.text: Click the link immediately to unlock.
Call the bank directly, don’t click anything.
Delete the email because it's not your bank.

correct3.title: Correct!
correct3.content: Never click on suspicious email links. Calling the bank or checking their official site is the safest option.

wrong3.title: Not quite!
wrong3.content: Hackers often impersonate banks to steal your data. Clicking might lead to stolen passwords or money!

4.title: Episode 4
4.content: You’re in a coffee shop and find a free Wi-Fi with no password. What will you do?

choices.text: Connect immediately and use social media as usual.
Connect to Wi-Fi but use a VPN to protect your data.
Don’t connect because of fear of data interception.

correct4.title: Better safe than sorry!
correct4.content: Avoiding insecure public Wi-Fi or using a VPN helps protect your personal data very well.

wrong4.title: Too risky!
wrong4.content: Public Wi-Fi can be used to intercept data without your knowledge. Never use it for logins or important transactions!

5.title: Episode 5
5.content: You're prompted to enable 2FA using an Authenticator app, but you're in a hurry. What will you do?

choices.text: Skip for now, set it up later.
Enable 2FA right away for security.
Use SMS-based 2FA instead because it's easier.

correct5.title: Great job!
correct5.content: Enabling 2FA helps protect your account even if someone knows your password. You made the right choice!

wrong5.title: Oh no...
wrong5.content: Just a password isn’t enough nowadays! Make sure you have 2FA turned on for added security.

6.title: Episode 6
6.content: You found a free app offering tons of rewards but it requests access to files, photos, and SMS. What will you do?

choices.text: Install it right away — who would pass up free stuff?
Read reviews, install only if it's trustworthy.
Don’t install it because the permissions are excessive.

correct6.title: Smart move!
correct6.content: Noticing apps requesting unnecessary permissions is a crucial skill. Avoid suspicious apps!

wrong6.title: Free but not safe!
wrong6.content: Apps asking for too many permissions may steal your data. Don’t fall for freebie traps!

7.title: Episode 7
7.content: You receive an SMS saying 'You won an iPhone' with a link. What will you do?

choices.text: Click it — maybe it’s real.
Verify the source first.
Delete it right away because it looks like a scam.

correct7.title: Not fooled!
correct7.content: You spotted a phishing attempt. Never click random links — great job!

wrong7.title: Nothing’s really free!
wrong7.content: Such links often steal personal info. Don’t risk your data for false hopes!

8.title: Episode 8
8.content: A friend messages you urgently asking for money. It's the same account but with strange typos. What will you do?

choices.text: Send the money immediately — it’s the same account.
Don’t overthink it, maybe your friend really needs help.
Call your friend every time to confirm.

correct8.title: Excellent!
correct8.content: Beware of impersonation scams. Just because it’s your friend’s name doesn’t mean it’s really them. Always call to check!

wrong8.title: Too easy to trick!
wrong8.content: Your friend’s account might be hacked, and the message could be from a scammer. Don’t send money immediately!

9.title: Episode 9
9.content: You find a USB flash drive in a parking lot and wonder who it belongs to. What will you do?

choices.text: Give it to security or responsible staff.
Plug it into a friend’s computer just to be safe.
Plug it into your computer to check the files immediately.

correct9.title: Better safe than sorry!
correct9.content: Unknown USB drives might contain viruses or malware. Give them to staff to handle safely.

wrong9.title: Very dangerous!
wrong9.content: A random USB might be infected. Plugging it in could compromise your system instantly!

10.title: Episode 10
10.content: You need to log in to your email on a public computer at an internet cafe. How can you stay safe?

choices.text: Use incognito mode and always log out.
Log in normally and log out properly afterward.
Avoid logging in on public computers — too risky.

correct10.title: Smart choice!
correct10.content: Avoiding logging in to important accounts on public computers greatly reduces the risk of data leakage!

wrong10.title: Watch out for keyloggers!
wrong10.content: Public computers might have password-stealing tools. Don’t take unnecessary risks!
